The twentieth century history of measurement is marked by five periods: the 1901 definition of the coherent MKS system; the intervening 50 years of coexistence of the MKS, cgs and common systems of measures; the 1948 "Practical system of units" prototype of the SI; the introduction of the SI in 1960; and the evolution of the SI in the latter half century.

Burlesque overlaps in meaning with caricature, parody and travesty, and, in its theatrical sense, with extravaganza, as presented during the Victorian era. "Burlesque" has been used in English in this literary and theatrical sense since the late 17th century. It has been applied retrospectively to works of Chaucer and Shakespeare and to the Graeco-Roman classics. Contrasting examples of literary burlesque are Alexander Pope's "The Rape of the Lock" and Samuel Butler's "Hudibras". An example of musical burlesque is Richard Strauss's 1890 Burleske for piano and orchestra. Examples of theatrical burlesques include W. S. Gilbert's "Robert the Devil" and the A. C. Torr – Meyer Lutz shows, including "Ruy Blas and the Blasé Roué".
Angelic tongues are the languages supposedly used by angels. It usually refers to sung praise in Second Temple period Jewish materials.

The Ford Mustang is an American car manufactured by Ford. It was originally based on the platform of the second generation North American Ford Falcon, a compact car. The original 1962 Ford Mustang I two-seater concept car had evolved into the 1963 Mustang II four-seater concept car which Ford used to pretest how the public would take interest in the first production Mustang. The 1963 Mustang II concept car was designed with a variation of the production model's front and rear ends with a roof that was 2.7 inches shorter. Introduced early on April 17, 1964 (16 days after the Plymouth Barracuda), and thus dubbed as a "1964½" by Mustang fans, the 1965 Mustang was the automaker's most successful launch since the Model A. The Mustang has undergone several transformations to its current sixth generation.

Horrible Bosses is a 2011 American black comedy film directed by Seth Gordon, written by Michael Markowitz, John Francis Daley, and Jonathan Goldstein, based on a story by Markowitz. It stars Jason Bateman, Charlie Day, Jason Sudeikis, Jennifer Aniston, Colin Farrell, Kevin Spacey, and Jamie Foxx. The plot follows three friends, played by Bateman, Day, and Sudeikis, who decide to murder their respective overbearing, abusive bosses, portrayed by Spacey, Aniston, and Farrell.

A symphonic poem or tone poem is a piece of orchestral music, usually in a single continuous movement, which illustrates or evokes the content of a poem, short story, novel, painting, landscape, or other (non-musical) source. The German term "Tondichtung (tone poem)" appears to have been first used by the composer Carl Loewe in 1828. The Hungarian composer Franz Liszt first applied the term "Symphonische Dichtung" to his 13 works in this vein.

Voima is a Finnish state-owned icebreaker. Built by Wärtsilä Hietalahti shipyard in Helsinki in 1954, she was the first icebreaker in the world to be equipped with two bow propellers and generated widespread publicity that helped the Finnish shipbuilding industry to become the world leader in icebreaker design.

The human wave attack, also known as the human sea attack, is an offensive infantry tactic in which an attacker conducts an unprotected frontal assault with densely concentrated infantry formations against the enemy line, intended to overrun the defenders by engaging in melee combat.

In 1973, the year after the Apollo lunar program ended, three Apollo CSM/Saturn IBs ferried crews to the Skylab space station. In 1975, one last Apollo/Saturn IB launched the Apollo portion of the joint US-USSR Apollo–Soyuz Test Project (ASTP). A backup Apollo CSM/Saturn IB was assembled and made ready for a Skylab rescue mission, but never flown.

Valve Corporation is an American video game developer, publisher and digital distribution company headquartered in Bellevue, Washington. It is the developer of the software distribution platform Steam and the "Half-Life", "Counter-Strike", "Portal", "Day of Defeat", "Team Fortress", "Left 4 Dead", and "Dota 2" games.

The painting is thought to be a portrait of Lisa Gherardini, the wife of Francesco del Giocondo, and is in oil on a white Lombardy poplar panel. It had been believed to have been painted between 1503 and 1506; however, Leonardo may have continued working on it as late as 1517. Recent academic work suggests that it would not have been started before 1513. It was acquired by King Francis I of France and is now the property of the French Republic, on permanent display at the Louvre Museum in Paris since 1797.

Beer is a beverage fermented from grain mash. It is typically made from barley or a blend of several grains and flavored with hops. Most beer is naturally carbonated as part of the fermentation process. If the fermented mash is distilled, then the drink becomes a spirit. In the Andean region, the most common beer is chicha, made from grain or fruits. Beer is the most consumed alcoholic beverage in the world.

Brotherus was born in Skarpans in Sund, Åland while Finland was under Russian rule. He had 13 brothers and sisters of whom six died young. He took his Candidate of Philosophy degree in 1870 at Imperial Alexander University (later University of Helsinki) and began medical studies but gave them up after getting blood poisoning and became a teacher. He married Aline Mathilde Sandman (born 1853), daughter of Jonas Sandman, a Justice in the Court of Appeal, in 1879 at the age of thirty, and had four children. She died in 1894 and he did not remarry. He taught natural history and mathematics at the Swedish girls' school in Vaasa City from 1878 to 1917, carrying on his career as a botanist in parallel. At his funeral, his grand-nephew describes:  "Foreign guests arrived to his funeral, he was praised in the funeral orations, last respects were read from distant lands. The staff of the school was astonished. They had no idea that he was also something else but their dear old junior lecturer [original in Finnish]."

Modern psychiatric hospitals evolved from, and eventually replaced the older lunatic asylums. The development of the modern psychiatric hospital is also the story of the rise of organized, institutional psychiatry.

The history of New Zealand dates back at least 700 years to when it was discovered and settled by Polynesians, who developed a distinct Māori culture centred on kinship links and land. The first European explorer to sight New Zealand was Dutch navigator Abel Tasman on 13 December 1642. The Dutch were also the first non-natives to explore and chart New Zealand's coastline. Captain James Cook, who reached New Zealand in October 1769 on the first of his three voyages, was the first European explorer to circumnavigate and map New Zealand. From the late 18th century, the country was regularly visited by explorers and other sailors, missionaries, traders and adventurers. In 1840 the Treaty of Waitangi was signed between the British Crown and various Māori chiefs, bringing New Zealand into the British Empire and giving Māori the same rights as British subjects. There was extensive British settlement throughout the rest of the century and into the early part of the next century. War and the imposition of a European economic and legal system led to most of New Zealand's land passing from Māori to Pākehā (European) ownership, and most Māori subsequently became impoverished.
Kari Ukkonen (born 19 February 1961 in Kuopio) is a Finnish former football player and current football manager. As player, Ukkonen was fielded as defender as well as midfielder.

The Moscow Peace Treaty was signed by Finland and the Soviet Union on 12 March 1940, and the ratifications were exchanged on 21 March. It marked the end of the 105-day Winter War. Finland had to cede border areas to the Soviet Union. The treaty was signed by Vyacheslav Molotov, Andrey Zhdanov and Aleksandr Vasilevsky for Soviet Union, and Risto Ryti, Juho Kusti Paasikivi, Rudolf Walden and Väinö Voionmaa for Finland.

Norðurturninn, which resumed construction in 2015, will be 110 meters tall at its final stage of completion. There are more buildings which are proposed to be over 100 meters high. The tallest of them is intended to be 150 meters high, which will surpass the tallest building in Norway, Finland and Denmark. That will make the tower the fourth-tallest in North Europe, after the 155 meter high Kaknästornet in Sweden, the 168-meter-high Näsinneula in Tampere, Finland and the 190-meter-high Turning Torso in Malmö, Sweden.

China, officially the People's Republic of China (PRC), is a country in East Asia and the world's most populous country, with a population of around /1e9 round 3 billion. Covering approximately , it is the third- or fourth-largest country by total area. Governed by the Communist Party of China, the state exercises jurisdiction over 22 provinces, five autonomous regions, four direct-controlled municipalities (Beijing, Tianjin, Shanghai, and Chongqing), and the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau.

Born in Leytonstone, Essex, Hitchcock entered the film industry in 1919 as a title card designer after training as a technical clerk and copy writer for a telegraph-cable company. He made his directorial debut with the silent film "The Pleasure Garden" (1925). His first successful film, "" (1927), helped to shape the thriller genre, while his 1929 film, "Blackmail", was the first British "". Two of his 1930s thrillers, "The 39 Steps" (1935) and "The Lady Vanishes" (1938), are ranked among the greatest British films of the 20th century.

The Diet of Porvoo (Finnish "Porvoon maapäivät", or unhistorically "Porvoon valtiopäivät"; Swedish "Borgå landtdag"), was the summoned legislative assembly to establish the Grand Principality of Finland in 1809 and the heir of the powers of the Swedish Riksdag of the Estates. The session of the Diet lasted from March to July 1809.

He was President of the Asiatic Society of Bengal in 1867 and proposed a scheme for a zoological garden in Calcutta. This was finally opened by the Prince of Wales in 1875. He took considerable interest in the wild animals and wrote a book on the tiger and procured living specimens of the pygmy hogs for the Zoological Society of London. He became a fellow of the Royal Society in 1877, wrote much on subjects connected with the practice of medicine in India, and was especially known for his studies on the poisonous snakes of that country and on the physiological effects produced by their venom ("Thanatophidia of India", 1872). He researched snake venom along with Thomas Lauder Brunton in 1867 with assistance of Dr F. C. Webb. The book was printed by the Indian government and illustrated by artists from the Calcutta School of Art. In 1879, he spoke on "The progress of epidemiology in India" (published in 1880). In 1900 he published his autobiography, "Recollections of my Life". Fayrer knew Persian, several Indian languages and Italian. He also took an interest in anthropology and interacted with Thomas Henry Huxley on the topic. He proposed that an Ethnological Congress be held by the Asiatic Society of Bengal in 1866. Although this exhibition was not held, the idea of an Ethnographic survey was realized a few years later by Herbert Hope Risley.

There has never been a Bentley model known as the "Mark IV": neither from the "old" W.O. Bentley firm, nor from Rolls-Royce after the takeover of Bentley Motors in 1931. The "Mark IV" appellation seems to have been created by Ian Fleming, and erroneously perpetuated since. In contradistinction to the films, James Bond's official car in the Ian Fleming novels was a grey 1933 Bentley convertible. The car featured a 4.5-litre engine with the Amherst Villiers supercharger. In the novels, no gadgets were installed; this was Bond's personal vehicle that is mentioned in "Casino Royale" as being a hobby that Bond enjoys working on. Its only armament, in the novels, is a .45 Colt Army Special revolver Bond keeps in the glove compartment. The novel version of the Bentley Mark IV was destroyed during a chase sequence in "Moonraker". The Bentley is also the very first Bond vehicle seen in the film series, although it was shown very briefly during Bond's first scene in "From Russia with Love" and mentioned only in passing in "Goldfinger". In "From Russia with Love", the only gadget known to be included was a car phone, which in 1963 was very uncommon. The film version of "Goldfinger" strongly implies that the Bentley was issued to Bond by Q-Branch, since he asks Q about the vehicle, only to be told that it had "had its day". He is given the Aston Martin instead.

The moons of Saturn are numerous and diverse, ranging from tiny moonlets less than 1 kilometer across to the enormous Titan, which is larger than the planet Mercury. Saturn has 62 moons with confirmed orbits, 53 of which have names and only 13 of which have diameters larger than 50 kilometers, as well as dense rings with complex orbital motions of their own. Seven Saturnian moons are large enough to be ellipsoidal in shape, yet only two of those, Titan and Rhea, are currently in hydrostatic equilibrium. Particularly notable among Saturn's moons are Titan, the second-largest moon in the Solar System (after Jupiter's Ganymede), with a nitrogen-rich Earth-like atmosphere and a landscape featuring dry river networks and hydrocarbon lakes found nowhere else in the solar system; and Enceladus since its chemical composition is similar to that of comets. In particular, Enceladus emits jets of gas and dust, which could indicate the presence of liquid water under its south pole region, and may have a global ocean below its surface.
Peter Alan Laird (born January 27, 1954) is an American comic book writer and artist best known for co-creating the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles with writer and artist Kevin Eastman.

Firearms of Japan were introduced in the 13th century by the Chinese, but saw little use. Portuguese firearms were introduced in 1543, and intense development followed, with strong local manufacture during the period of conflicts of the late 16th century.

Occitania (, , , ) is the historical region and a nation, in southern Europe where Occitan was historically the main language spoken, and where it is sometimes still used, for the most part as a second language. This cultural area roughly encompasses the southern third of France, as well as part of Spain (Aran Valley), Monaco, and smaller parts of Italy (Occitan Valleys, Guardia Piemontese). Occitania has been recognized as a linguistic and cultural concept since the Middle Ages, but has never been a legal nor a political entity under this name, although the territory was united in Roman times as the "Seven Provinces" () and in the Early Middle Ages ("Aquitanica" or the Visigothic Kingdom of Toulouse, or the share of Louis the Pious following Thionville "divisio regnorumi" in 806).

Elsa Einstein (18 January 1876 – 20 December 1936) was the second wife and cousin of Albert Einstein. Their mothers were sisters, making them first cousins, and further, their fathers were first cousins, making them second cousins. Elsa had the surname of Einstein at birth, lost it when she took the name of her first husband Max Löwenthal, and regained it in 1919 when she married her cousin Albert.

Generally, work engagement is conceptualized as a relatively stable phenomenon. This can be explained by the presence of specific job and organizational characteristics. However, engagement is not a fixed state: the level of engagement can even fluctuate on a weekly or day-to-day basis. Increasingly, attention is being paid to these short-term fluctuations by conducting experience sampling studies and diary studies. Christian, Garza, and Slaughter (2011) meta-analyzed over 90 engagement research studies. They found that engagement is distinct from job satisfaction, organizational commitment, and job involvement.[15]

The exact origins of the early Finnish horse are currently not known. Because the Finnhorse breed and its progenitors were the only horses in Finland for centuries, the history of horses in Finland parallels the history of the Finnhorse itself. The documented history of the distinct breed begins at the turn of the 13th century. Outside influences by many light and warmblood breeds were recorded beginning in the 16th century, making the breed larger and more usable. An official Finnhorse studbook was founded in 1907, producing purebred animals in significant numbers for many years. Due to mechanisation of agriculture and the dismantling of Finnish horse cavalry in the later half of the 20th century, the Finnhorse population plummeted from a high of just over 400,000 animals in the 1950s to a low of 14,100 in 1987. However, the breed managed to survive thanks to its popularity for harness racing and its versatility as a mount.

The Shining is a horror novel by American author Stephen King. Published in 1977, it is King's third published novel and first hardback bestseller: the success of the book firmly established King as a preeminent author in the horror genre. The setting and characters are influenced by King's personal experiences, including both his visit to The Stanley Hotel in 1974 and his recovery from alcoholism. The novel was followed by a sequel, "Doctor Sleep", published in 2013.
This phenomenon was first observed in a 1938 experiment performed by Herbert E. Ives and G.R. Stilwell, called the Ives–Stilwell experiment.

Verona is famous for its Roman amphitheatre, the Arena, found in the city's largest piazza, the Piazza Bra. Completed around 30 AD, it is the third largest in Italy after Rome's Colosseum and the arena at Capua. It measures 139 metres long and 110 metres wide, and could seat some 25,000 spectators in its 44 tiers of marble seats. The "ludi" (shows and gladiator games) performed within its walls were so famous that they attracted spectators from far beyond the city. The current two-story façade is actually the internal support for the tiers; only a fragment of the original outer perimeter wall in white and pink limestone from Valpolicella, with three stories remains.The interior is very impressive and is virtually intact, and has remained in use even today for public events, fairs, theatre and open-aired opera during warm summer nights. There is also a variety of other Roman monuments to be found in the town, such as the Roman theatre of Verona. This theatre was built in the 1st century BC, but through the ages had fallen in disuse and had been built upon to provide housing. In the 18th century Andrea Monga, a wealthy Veronese, bought all the houses that in time had been built over the theatre, demolished them, and saved the monument. Not far from it is the Ponte di Pietra ("Stone Wall Bridge"), another Roman landmark that has survived to this day.
Catton died on January 5, 2015.
In human blood, glutamine is the most abundant free amino acid.

A citadel is the core fortified area of a town or city. It may be a castle, fortress, or fortified center. The term is a diminutive of "city" and thus means "little city", so called because it is a smaller part of the city of which it is the defensive core. Ancient Sparta had a citadel as did many other Greek cities and towns.

Electric guitars can have solid, semi-hollow, or hollow bodies; solid bodies produce little sound without amplification. Electromagnetic pickups, and sometimes piezoelectric pickups, convert the vibration of the steel strings into signals, which are fed to an amplifier through a patch cable or radio transmitter. The sound is frequently modified by other electronic devices (effects units) or the natural distortion of valves (vacuum tubes) or the pre-amp in the amplifier. There are two main types of magnetic pickups, single- and double-coil (or humbucker), each of which can be passive or active. The electric guitar is used extensively in jazz, blues, R & B, and rock and roll. The first successful magnetic pickup for a guitar was invented by George Beauchamp, and incorporated into the 1931 Ro-Pat-In (later Rickenbacker) "Frying Pan" lap steel; other manufacturers, notably Gibson, soon began to install pickups in archtop models. After World War II the completely solid-body electric was popularized by Gibson in collaboration with Les Paul, and independently by Leo Fender of Fender Music. The lower fretboard action (the height of the strings from the fingerboard), lighter (thinner) strings, and its electrical amplification lend the electric guitar to techniques less frequently used on acoustic guitars. These include tapping, extensive use of legato through pull-offs and hammer-ons (also known as slurs), pinch harmonics, volume swells, and use of a tremolo arm or effects pedals.

Oak wood has a density of about creating great strength and hardness. The wood is very resistant to insect and fungal attack because of its high tannin content. It also has very appealing grain markings, particularly when quartersawn. Oak planking was common on high status Viking longships in the 9th and 10th centuries. The wood was hewn from green logs, by axe and wedge, to produce radial planks, similar to quarter-sawn timber. Wide, quarter-sawn boards of oak have been prized since the Middle Ages for use in interior panelling of prestigious buildings such as the debating chamber of the House of Commons in London and in the construction of fine furniture. Oak wood, from "Quercus robur" and "Quercus petraea", was used in Europe for the construction of ships, especially naval men of war, until the 19th century, and was the principal timber used in the construction of European timber-framed buildings. Today oak wood is still commonly used for furniture making and flooring, timber frame buildings, and veneer production.

How and when horses became domesticated is disputed. The clearest evidence of early use of the horse as a means of transport is from chariot burials dated c. 2000 BCE. However, an increasing amount of evidence supports the hypothesis that horses were domesticated in the Eurasian Steppes approximately 3500 BCE; recent discoveries in the context of the Botai culture suggest that Botai settlements in the Akmola Province of Kazakhstan are the location of the earliest domestication of the horse.

The retractor penis muscle occurs in marsupials and carnivorans, but it is absent in humans. A stag's penis forms an S-shaped curve when it is not erect, and is retracted into its preputial sheath by the retractor penis muscle.

Kepler-37b is an extrasolar planet (exoplanet) orbiting Kepler-37 in the constellation Lyra. it is the smallest planet discovered around a main-sequence star, with a radius slightly greater than that of the Moon. The measurements do not constrain its mass, but masses above a few times that of the Moon give unphysically high densities.

The origin of the armed conflict in Colombia goes back to 1920 with agrarian disputes over the Sumapaz and Tequendama regions. Peasants at the time fought over ownership of coffee lands which caused the liberals and conservative parties to take sides in the conflict, worsening it.

The most important contributions to improving the status of Finnish were made by Elias Lönnrot. His impact on the development of modern vocabulary in Finnish was particularly important. In addition to compiling the "Kalevala", he acted as an arbiter in disputes about the development of standard Finnish between the proponents of western and eastern dialects, ensuring that the western dialects Agricola had preferred preserved their preeminent role, while many originally dialect words from Eastern Finland were introduced to the standard language, enriching it considerably. The first novel written in Finnish (and by a Finnish speaker) was "Seven Brothers" ("Seitsemän veljestä"), published by Aleksis Kivi in 1870.

Brazil ( ), officially the Federative Republic of Brazil (, ), is the largest country in both South America and Latin America. At 8.5 million square kilometers (3.2 million square miles) and with over 208 million people, Brazil is the world's fifth-largest country by area and the fifth most populous. The capital is Brasília, and the most populated city is São Paulo. The federation is composed of the union of the 26 states, the Federal District, and the 5,570 municipalities. It is the largest country to have Portuguese as an official language and the only one in the Americas; it is also one of the most multicultural and ethnically diverse nations, due to over a century of mass immigration from around the world.

Half-Life (stylized as HλLF-LIFE) is a first-person shooter video game developed by Valve and published by Sierra Studios for Microsoft Windows in 1998. It was Valve's debut product and the first in the "Half-Life" series. Players assume the role of Dr. Gordon Freeman, who must fight his way out of the Black Mesa research facility after an experiment goes wrong, fighting enemies and solving puzzles.

The first recorded instance of a colonist identifying as an "Afrikaner" occurred in March 1707, during a disturbance in Stellenbosch. When the magistrate, Johannes Starrenburg, ordered an unruly crowd to desist, a white teenager named Hendrik Biebouw retorted, ""Ik ben een Afrikaander - al slaat de landdrost mij dood, of al zetten hij mij in de tronk, ik zal, nog wil niet zwijgen!"" ("I am an African - even if the magistrate were to beat me to death, or put me in jail, I shall not be, nor will I stay, silent!"). Biebouw was flogged for his insolence and later banished to Jakarta. It is believed that "Afrikaner" in question initially indicated Cape Coloureds or other groups claiming mixed ancestry. Biebouw himself had numerous half-caste siblings and may have identified with Coloureds socially. However, this defiant secession from Dutch law and sovereignty was a leap towards defining another consciousness for white South Africa, suggesting for the first time a group identification with the Cape Colony rather than any ancestral homeland in Europe.

In 1795, a Third Partition of Poland was undertaken by Russia, Prussia and Austria as a final division of territory that resulted in the effective dissolution of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth. King Stanisław August Poniatowski was escorted to Grodno, forced to abdicate, and retired to Saint Petersburg. Tadeusz Kościuszko, initially imprisoned, was allowed to emigrate to the United States in 1796.

Europe covers about , or 2% of the Earth's surface (6.8% of land area). Politically, Europe is divided into about fifty sovereign states of which the Russian Federation is the largest and most populous, spanning 39% of the continent and comprising 15% of its population. Europe had a total population of about 741 million (about 11% of the world population) . The European climate is largely affected by warm Atlantic currents that temper winters and summers on much of the continent, even at latitudes along which the climate in Asia and North America is severe. Further from the sea, seasonal differences are more noticeable than close to the coast.

The Colombian Civil War began on May 8, 1860, and lasted until November 1862. It was an internal conflict between the newly formed conservative Granadine Confederation and a more liberal rebel force from the newly seceded region of Cauca, composed of dissatisfied politicians commanded by General Tomás Cipriano de Mosquera, its former president. The Granadine Confederation, created a few years earlier in 1858 by Mariano Ospina Rodríguez, was defeated in the capital Bogotá, with Mosquera deposing the newly elected president Bartolomé Calvo on July 18, 1861. Forming a provisional government, with himself as president, Mosquera continued to pursue the conservative forces until their final defeat in 1862. The resulting formation of the new United States of Colombia would have significant cultural and economic consequences for Colombia.

Christopher Reeve played Superman/Clark Kent in the Superman film series, "Superman: The Movie" (1978), "Superman II" (1980), "Superman III" (1983), and "" (1987). Like Kirk Alyn, Reeve was so closely identified with the character that it was difficult for him to acquire lead parts in other films. He was largely relegated to "Superman" sequels and supporting roles. Reeve was paralyzed from the neck down after being thrown from his horse in a cross-country equestrian riding event on May 27, 1995. Reeve died on October 10, 2004, of heart failure stemming from his medical condition.

DDR3 prototypes were announced in early 2005. Products in the form of motherboards appeared on the market in June 2007 based on Intel's P35 "Bearlake" chipset with DIMMs at bandwidths up to DDR3-1600 (PC3-12800). The Intel Core i7, released in November 2008, connects directly to memory rather than via a chipset. The Core i7 supports only DDR3. AMD's first socket AM3 Phenom II X4 processors, released in February 2009, were their first to support DDR3.

Intermolecular forces (IMF) are the forces which mediate interaction between molecules, including forces of attraction or repulsion which act between molecules and other types of neighboring particles, e.g., atoms or ions. Intermolecular forces are weak relative to intramolecular forces – the forces which hold a molecule together. For example, the covalent bond, involving sharing electron pairs between atoms, is much stronger than the forces present between neighboring molecules. Both sets of forces are essential parts of force fields frequently used in molecular mechanics.

Debuting in the Silver Age of Comic Books, the character first appeared in "Journey into Mystery" #83 (August 1962) and was created by editor-plotter Stan Lee, scripter Larry Lieber, and penciller-plotter Jack Kirby. He has starred in several ongoing series and limited series, and is a founding member of the superhero team the Avengers, appearing in each volume of that series. The character has also appeared in associated Marvel merchandise including animated television series, movies, video games, clothing, toys and trading cards.

The flag of Nigeria is the official flag of the Federal Republic of Nigeria. It was designed in 1959 and was officially put into use on October 1, 1960. The green color of the flag represents forests and natural wealth, and the white represents peace. The flag was created based on a design competition. The competition was won by a student from Ibadan, Michael Taiwo Akinkunmi, who had admired the green nature of his country when he flew to London to continue his studies and, influenced by it, chose green as the main color of the proposal, but the competition jury left the red sun in the middle of the flag off the flag in Akinkunmi's proposal.

The transition state is the point on the reaction coordinate of a chemical reaction where the group of atoms has the highest Gibbs energy value. It can be considered as an intermediate form of reacting compounds and products. The reaction can proceed from the transition state towards products or decompose into starting materials. Sometimes the transition state is called an activated complex, but according to the IUPAC definition, it is a different thing. A transition state is typically marked in the chemical literature by placing it in square brackets and marking it with a double cross ‡. The transition state is unstable and very short-lived. It usually takes about 10 seconds. The transition state is not an actual molecule, because more bonds can leave the atom than the valence rules would allow and the bonds are not necessarily fully formed. From 1940 to 1990, the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (, ) or Lithuanian SNT (, ) was one of the Soviet republics belonging to the Soviet Union. After the Soviet Union occupied Lithuania on June 12, 1940, the country was named Lithuanian SNT on July 21, 1940. Originally, the Lithuanian SNT was founded much earlier in December 1918, when the first congress of the Lithuanian Communist Party was held on October 1 of the same year. According to the Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact, Lithuania belonged to the Soviet Union's front circle and the country became the 14th Soviet republic in order. The German Empire occupied the Soviet Socialist Republic of Lithuania in the early stages of Operation Barbarossa, and after military rule by the Wehrmacht, annexed it to its civilian administration as the Main Administrative District of Lithuania. The Vicar of Dibley () is a British sitcom created by Richard Curtis and written for its lead actress Dawn French. The series was shown between 1994 and 2007. It takes place in the small fictional village of Dibley in Oxfordshire, where a female vicar is appointed as a result of the change in the Church of England in 1992 that allowed the ordination of women. The main character was an invention of Richard Curtis, but he and Dawn French consulted a lot with Joy Carroll, who was one of the first female priests in the Church of England, and got a lot of character traits and a lot of information from her. In March 2007, Curtis received an Academy Fellowship from the British Academy of Film and Television Arts for his humanitarian efforts as well as his work, including "The Vicar of Dibley". around the 14th century BC. The urbanization of Rome must have started in the 7th century BC. Over the centuries, Rome developed into a world power surrounding the Mediterranean. The story of the founding of Rome is a fable that describes the founding of the city of Rome. According to the legend, Rome was founded on April 21, 753 BC. twin brothers Romulus and Remus. There are different versions of the founding story. The Greek fable developed perhaps in the 5th century BC. It became associated with the Roman founding myth in the 2nd century in the time of Roman historians writing in Greek. In reality, Rome was never actually founded, but developed into a city over a long period of time. According to legend, the twin brothers Romulus and Remus who founded Rome were descendants of Aeneas of Troy and Numitor, king of the Latins of Alba Longa. King Numitor had been dethroned by his cruel brother Amulius when Numitor's daughter Rhea Silvia was about to give birth. Rhea Silvia was a Vesta virgin made by Mars, the god of war

by October 2, 2008. In addition to its hardware, Nintendo has become known for its many game titles such as "Mario", "Donkey Kong", "Kirby", "Metroid", "Pokémon" and "The Legend of Zelda". Fusajirō Yamauchi founded Nintendo on September 23, 1889 as "Nintendō koppai". The name "Nintendo" is Japanese and means "leave happiness in heaven" in Finnish. The company was founded in Kyoto, Japan and produced and marketed Hanafuda playing cards. A miniature model is a significantly smaller copy of an object, building or other object than the original. Common are e.g. Vehicle-themed miniature models, as well as dolls, dollhouses and miniature rooms. Miniature models are used a lot to help architects' planning to illustrate the massing of the future building and its placement in its surroundings. In this field, the importance of miniature models has decreased, because the illustration of plans is also possible with the help of three-dimensional computer models. A miniature model can also be built from a building group or area of ​​the past. For example, the Museo della Civiltà Romana in Rome has a miniature model of the Roman city of the imperial period, and Lappeenranta has a miniature model of Vyborg from 1939. Miniature models are also used as an aid in car, ship and airplane design. The models can be used, for example, in wind tunnels to find out the air resistance of the final product. Personality disorders are developmental conditions classified as mental health disorders that begin in childhood or adolescence and continue into adulthood. Personality disorders can cause serious problems and impaired functioning for people who suffer from them. According to the American Psychiatric Association, personality disorders are persistent patterns of mental experience and behavior that deviate significantly from the expectations of the person's own culture. These models are in many cases inflexible and unrelenting. The onset of the pattern can be traced at least to the beginning of adulthood. To be diagnosed as a personality disorder, the behavior pattern must cause significant distress or clear impairment in personal, social or work situations. The line between personality disorder and behavior considered normal is a slippery one. Most mentally healthy people show ways of experiencing or behaving that are characteristic of different personality disorders, especially in stressful situations.

Amino acids are organic compounds that have both an amino (-NH) and a carboxyl group (-COOH) attached to the same molecule. The amino group is basic and the carboxyl group is acidic. Amino acids polymerize into polypeptides. When the length of the polypeptide chain exceeds 50, it is usually called a protein. There are 20 essential amino acids for humans, 11 of which the body can produce itself. The remaining nine essential amino acids must be obtained from food. In cells, amino acids are produced under the control of enzymes. Amino acids most commonly occur at physiological pH (pH 7.4) as zwitterions, where the carboxyl group is negatively charged and the amino group is positively charged. If the amino group of an amino acid has bound a hydrogen atom donated by the carboxyl group of the same amino acid, the event is called internal salt formation. Gujarati is an Indo-Aryan language. Most of its speakers live in India and it is the main language of the state of Gujarat. Gujarati has the status of a national language in India. In addition, it is a minority language in countries such as Pakistan, Kenya and Tanzania. More than 46 million people speak Gujarati as their mother tongue, making it about the 23rd most spoken language in the world. Word order in Gujarati is subject-object-verb. There are no indefinite or definite articles in the language. Nouns have three genders and two grammatical numbers. The vocabulary of the language has been influenced by Arabia and Persia, and today, especially in colloquial English and Portuguese. Gujarati is written with its own alphabet, Gujarati letters. Arabic and Persian alphabets have also been used sometimes. The Bible was translated into Gujarati

Croatia is geographically divided into three parts. It includes a rocky coastline with more than 600 rocky islands, the northern and northeastern Pannonian lowlands with the Sava, Drava and Danube rivers, and the forested mountain ranges in between. The mountains are especially known for karst deposits, where water has carved out complex surface formations up to over a kilometer deep caves. The climate is mostly temperate, but in the north and east there is a continental climate with cold winters and warm summers, and a Mediterranean climate on the coast. In the northern parts of Croatia, a cold, gusty wind, the bora, sometimes blows during the winter. The head of state (also head of state) is the monarch in monarchies, the president in most republics. Despite the ending of the word man, the head of state can also be a woman. Usually, the head of state is the highest political power wielder of the state, but today it is also possible that his position is mainly representative, ceremonial and symbolic, in which case the prime minister is usually the supreme power wielder. Throughout history, there have been different positions of head of state, and many different titles and titles have been used for the head of state. Today, the head of state is typically the president in republics, in monarchies a monarch such as a king (queen), emperor (emperor), prince (princess), emir or pope, or as the monarch's representative the governor-general or, in the absence of the monarch, a deputy ruler or regent. The bond number describes the degree of bonding of the atoms bonded to each other in a molecular compound. The bond order number is compared to the single bond formed by one pair of electrons. The order of two pairs of electrons, i.e. the double bond, is 2 and the triple bond is 3. According to the molecular orbital theory, the bond order is the difference between the electrons located in the bonding orbitals and the orbitals located in the dissociating orbitals divided by two. Most often, the bond order number is a whole number, but it can also be a fractional number. This is typical for compounds whose structures have several resonance modes, for example the bond order of benzene is 1.5. The bond order number can be used as a qualitative measure of bond strength. The higher the bond order number, the stronger the bond is, and then the bond length is also shorter and the bond energy is higher than with a lower bond order number.

The flag of Niger is the symbol of Niger together with the national anthem (La Nigérienne), coat of arms and motto ("Fraternité, Travail, Progrès"). The flag was confirmed as the national emblem on November 23, 1959. The flag is a horizontal striped tricolor with the colors orange, white and green. The white field also has an orange ball in the middle. According to the general explanation, the orange stripe symbolizes the Sahara desert in the north of the country or the grasses of the savannas, white for purity (some say the Niger River), green for both hope and the forests of the south of the country, and the orange ball for either the sun or independence.

In nuclear magnetic resonance-based NMR spectroscopy, chemical shift means a change in the resonance frequency of the magnetic nucleus relative to the reference sample. The shift is defined as the relative difference between the resonance frequency of the investigated material and the resonance frequency of the reference compound and is denoted by the symbol "δ". The chemical shift depends on the chemical environment of the magnetic core, which can be used in molecular structure research. In compounds, magnetic atomic nuclei oscillate in an external magnetic field at a resonance frequency characteristic of each atomic nucleus. Also, the resonance frequencies of nuclei that are similar but in different chemical environments differ slightly from each other. These frequencies are compared to a reference standard and the difference is called the chemical shift. The electrons orbit the proton and create a magnetic field that weakens the effect of the external magnetic field on the proton. This phenomenon is called hedging. The Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (, , LSSR) was a short-lived Soviet republic. It was founded on December 16, 1918 by the revolutionary government led by Vincas Mickevičius-Kapsukas. The Lithuanian Soviet Republic ceased to exist on February 27, 1919, after it merged with the Belarusian Soviet Socialist Republic to become the Lithuanian-Belarusian Soviet Socialist Republic. Although the leadership of the Lithuanian Soviet Republic presented the state as having been founded by Lithuanian workers, it was mainly a puppet state of Soviet Russia and the cause of the Lithuanian–Soviet Russian War. Lithuanians generally did not support the Soviet sentiment and pushed for their own national Republic of Lithuania, whose independence was declared by the Council of Lithuania on February 16, 1918. The German Empire lost the First World War and signed the Armistice of Compiègne on November 11, 1918. The German army began to withdraw from the territories of the former Ober Ost. Two days later, the leadership of Soviet Russia abdicated

The Roman Empire (often also ancient Rome) was a vast empire that grew from the ancient city-state of Rome, which encompassed the entire Mediterranean region. The earliest signs of settlement in the area of ​​the city of Rome are from the Bronze Age, around the 14th century BC. Urbanization probably started in the 7th century BC. Over the centuries, Rome developed into a world power surrounding the Mediterranean. In 395, the empire split into two, the Western and Eastern Roman Empires, of which Western Rome fell already in 476, when its last emperor was deposed. Attempts to unify the Roman Empire under the leadership of Eastern Rome ended with the rise of Islam in the 6th century. Still, Eastern Rome, or Byzantium, existed, albeit with a considerably reduced area, until the Turkish occupation of Constantinople in 1453. In addition, the Empire of Trebizond survived until 1461 and the Principality of Theodoro until 1475. Information

The Italian region has been the core region of the Roman Empire in the past. After the collapse of the empire in 476, the region was divided into numerous small principalities. The Italian state was founded in 1861. Italy is a founding member of both the EU and NATO. According to the International Monetary Fund, Italy's purchasing power adjusted gross domestic product in 2018 is approximately 2.4 trillion US dollars. Italy is located in southern Europe, on the Apennine Peninsula, a narrow peninsula dominated by the mountain range of the same name. Italy is bordered in the north by the Alps and the countries of Switzerland and Austria, in the northeast by Slovenia, in the northwest by France, in the east by the Adriatic Sea, in the west by the Ligurian Sea and the Tyrrhenian Sea, in the south by the Ionian Sea and the Straits of Malta and Sicily. In addition to the Apennine peninsula, Italy includes several islands, including the largest Mediterranean islands Sicily and Sardinia, as well as Elba, Capri, Ischia, Panteleria

Personality is a whole made up of thoughts, feelings and behavior, which is characteristic of each person and fairly permanent in different situations and at different times. Personality partly has a genetic basis, but it also changes and develops throughout life through the interaction of the individual and his environment, especially during childhood. There is no single established definition of personality in the field of psychology, and the concept is used in different ways. What most definitions of personality have in common is that personality refers to both a person's external activity, visible to other people, and the person's internal, private world of experience. Omega-3 fatty acids are polyunsaturated fatty acids whose first double bond in the carbon chain, counted from the end of the methyl group, is in the third carbon-carbon bond. Omega-3 fatty acids include alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), which is an essential fatty acid for humans, docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), and eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA). A person must get alpha-linolenic acid and DHA fatty acid from food. The human body is able to produce some EPA fatty acid from alpha-linolenic acid, but it is not necessarily produced in the optimum amount for health, which is why it is recommended to add fatty fish or fish oil to the diet. In 2008, the Harvard University Information Center suggested that the human body could not produce eicosapentaenoic acid EPA or docosahexaenoic acid DHA, and therefore recommended regular consumption of fatty fish or, alternatively, consumption of EPA and DHA extracted from algae. Council of Lithuania (, , ), after July 11, 1918, the Council of State of Lithuania ("Lietuvos Valstysty Taryba") was a council operating in Lithuania with the purpose of creating an independent Republic of Lithuania. The Council was established in September 1917 at the Vilnius Conference as a group of Lithuanians enjoying executive power. On February 16, 1918, the members of the Council signed the Lithuanian Declaration of Independence, declaring Lithuania an independent republic based on democratic principles. The Soviet managed to create a declaration of independence despite the presence of German soldiers who were in Lithuania until the fall of 1918. The Council of Lithuania continued to function until the Constituent Assembly, which began on May 15, 1920. After the final partition of Poland in 1795, Lithuania became part of the Russian Empire. Horses have appeared in Finland since prehistoric times. Horse equipment has been found in Central Iron Age graves. There has hardly ever been a population of wild horses in Finland. Emir (; amīrah, ãmir; Persian and Urdu: امیر) is the title of a tribal chief in the Arab world. Emirs are usually considered high-ranking sheikhs, but the title is also used, like "prince", for some monarchs, in which case their kingdom is called an emirate. Emirs are also appointed by some Turkic nations. The emir has always been a high military rank. The western word admiral is derived from the emir rank Amir al-bahr, naval commander. The Arabic word "ãmir" meaning leader or commander comes from the word "amr", .

The coat of arms of Nigeria is the emblem of Nigeria along with the flag, national anthem and motto. It was introduced in 1960 when the country gained independence. The shield of the coat of arms has a white undulating Y pattern on a black background. The picture depicts two rivers flowing in Nigeria, Niger and Benue. The black color symbolizes the fertility of the area. Above the shield is a braid with the colors of the Nigerian flag. The red eagle on the helmet and the horses standing on their hind legs as the shield bearers depict the national sense of self-worth and strength. Below the shield is the motto "Unity and Faith, Peace and Progress".

The 2000 United States House of Representatives election was held on November 7. It was on the same day as the disputed presidential election in which George W. Bush was elected president of the United States. In the House of Representatives elections, the Democratic Party won additional seats for the third time in a row, and reduced the lead of the Republican Party, which is still in the majority, to only nine seats. Republicans won a total of 221 seats in the House of Representatives, while Democrats won 212 seats. Only two candidates from outside the ruling parties made it to the House of Representatives: non-aligned Bernie Sanders and Virgil Goode. The future president of the United States, Barack Obama, tried to be the Democratic candidate in the first electoral district of Illinois, but did not get the party's nomination. The 2000 election was the last one to use areas drawn from the 1990 census as constituencies.

The Lithuanian Nationalist League (, LTS) was a Lithuanian nationalist, right-wing and in some areas also a fascist party. The Nationalist League was the leading party in Lithuania after the 1926 coup d'état from 1926 to 1940. The party was re-founded after Lithuania's independence in 1990. Still, party leaders Antanas Smetona and Augustinas Voldemaras were well-known and influential figures. The party was strongly conservative and nationalist and emphasized the importance of a strong military and leader. The Pori city flood was a heavy rain flood that occurred in Pori on August 12, 2007. It damaged more than a thousand properties, their chattels and a large number of vehicles. It was Finland's biggest urban flood of all time. The heavy rain that caused the flood started on Sunday, August 12 at around 16:00 and lasted just under three hours. During that period, according to estimates, the precipitation was 100-130 mm. There is no exact information on the amount of rain, because it was limited to a narrow area in the center of Pori and nearby neighborhoods, where the official measuring points of the Finnish Meteorological Institute are not located. However, the amount of rain during the three hours was greater than the average rainfall in the area for the whole of August. Joseph Smith Fletcher (7 February 1863 Halifax, West Yorkshire – 30 January 1935 Dorking, Surrey) was an English journalist and author. British mystery writer Joseph Smith Fletcher was born in Halifax, the son of a clergyman. He was orphaned by his father at the age of eight months. His grandmother, who lives in Darrington near Pontefract, took him to her farm to raise him. Joseph completed his qualifications at Silcoates School in Wakefield. At the age of 18, he moved to London to become a journalist. He worked in a few newspapers, although he was not yet a reporter. After studying law for a while, he started as an assistant editor at the age of 20. At times he returned to his native Yorkshire. He eventually ended up as a freelance writer. Fletcher married the Irish writer Rosamond Langbridge. The family had one son, Valentine Fletcher, who served as a priest in various parishes in Yorkshire

Linnainen () is a district in the southwest corner of Vantaa, near the Espoo border. Linnainen is located in the southwest corner of Vantaa and borders Espoo in the south and west, Hämeenkylä in the north and Hämeenkylä and Hämeevaara and Askisto in the east. Linnaistentie goes through Linnainen and ends at Ainontie, which runs past Linnainen manor on the shore of Lake Pitkäjärvi. Ainontie is the medieval Turku-Viipuri road, or the Great Beach Road (Kuninkaantie). The central part of the castles is divided by Rajatorpantie, which leads from the center of the large area from Myyrmäki to the Espoo side. Linnainen got its name from the Linnainen mansion, from which plots were divided in the 1950s. The original name of the house was Skinnars (1556), which means tanner's house. Suspicious personality is a personality disorder that includes, in addition to suspicion, excessive sensitivity to setbacks, distortion of experiences, and the inability to forgive insults. The disease is considered to start most often in early adulthood and is estimated to occur more often in males than females. Estimates of the prevalence of the disease in the population vary between 0.5 and 2.5 percent. The assessment of prevalence has been complicated by the problem of differential diagnosis with paranoid schizophrenia. People with a suspicious personality often doubt their partner's loyalty. Suspicious personality sufferers are often hostile, violent and involved in lawsuits. Suspicious personality sufferers have a combative and stubborn awareness of their own rights. In the treatment of suspicious personality, supportive psychotherapy based on a confidential treatment relationship (= supportive psychotherapy) is considered to be the most important. Rear admiral (abbreviated as kamir) is a high military rank used by the navies of several countries, below vice admiral and equivalent to major general of the ground and air forces. In Finland, it was the lowest rank of admirals until the 1990s, but at that time, in connection with the establishment of the rank of brigadier general of the land and air forces, a new corresponding rank of flag admiral was created, which ranks below rear admiral. The rear admiral is addressed as admiral, without the prefix.

André da Silva (born November 26, 1972) is a Brazilian sprinter. Da Silva qualified for the 1992 Barcelona Olympics in the heats of the 100 meters with a time of 10.78. The following year, he qualified for the World Indoor Championships in Toronto in the preliminaries of the 200 meters with a time of 21.66. Later that year, he was second at the South American Championships in the 200m and qualified for the Stuttgart Outdoor World Championships in the 200m heats with a time of 20.99. At the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, da Silva qualified in the second heats of the 100 meters after running 10.26, but was part of the Brazilian team that won Olympic bronze in the 4 x 100 meters relay. The following year, he qualified for the World Indoor Championships in Paris in the preliminaries of the 60-meter run with a time of 6.70. Later that year was second in the South American championships in 100 meters

A republic is a form of government in which there is no head at all or the head (usually the president) is elected for a fixed term. The designation also means the state where such a system is in force. The administration of a democratic republic is based on the power of parliamentarians. The rule of law is one of the basic conditions of a republic. A republic is often called the opposite of a monarchy. The definition is usable, but not valid in some borderline cases, and not when the difference between republic and monarchy is defined differently than in modern society. The concept of oligarchy does not fit either option either. The concept of a republic as unequivocally the opposite of a monarchy is too general and does not take into account, for example, the diversity of different monarchies (see form of government). Pan-African colors are green, gold and red or green, black and red. The green, gold and red are based on the flag of Ethiopia, which was the only African country not to be colonized, despite the attempts of Western countries. Green, black and red are again based on the colors of the US-based "Universal Negro Improvement Association and African Communities League" (UNIA). Ghana was the first to adopt Pan-African colors on its flag in 1957, after which more than twenty African countries have followed its example. Pan-African colors are also used in some non-African countries with a significant African diaspora (such as Jamaica). Norns are goddesses of fate in Scandinavian mythology. They resemble the Fates of ancient fairy tales. There are three Norns: siblings "Urd" ("fate"), "Verdandi" ("development") and "Skuld" ("guilt"). They regulate the destinies of gods and humans alike and the immutable laws of the world. Norns live in Asgård, at the foot of the world tree Yggdrasil and by the well of Urd, where they spin the thread of destiny for each person born. According to one legend, Urd spins the threads, Verdandi twists them together, and Skuld cuts the thread. However, nothing lasts forever, and even Yggdrasil is bound to wither. The Norns try to prevent this, or at least slow down the process, by pouring mud and water from the well of fate on the roots of the world tree. The magical liquid stops the rotting for the time being. Norn myths

A piggery is an agricultural building where pigs are raised. Pigs usually live in pens, where there are usually dozens of pigs. Pig pens and pig pens have different requirements than, for example, living areas for sheep or cows: Meat pigs usually have a pen with a concrete and grate base, from which the manure flows through the grate into the slurry tank. The piggery is completely dependent on mechanical ventilation: if the electricity goes out, the pigs die from lack of oxygen as the ammonia secreted from their manure fills the air space. Newborn pigs, or piglets, usually live in a sow piggery. At the age of just over two months, the piglets are sold to fattening pigs. However, the best individuals are left in the sow fish to continue the breed. With the industrialization of agricultural production, the so-called piglets. In Finland, the average size of a piggery is 100–200 pigs, but piggeries of several hundred pigs are becoming more common.

In biology, gender is an anatomical characteristic that occurs in species that reproduce by family, on the basis of which individuals can usually be divided into individuals that produce eggs, i.e. females (fertilizing) and individuals that produce sperm cells, i.e. males (fertilizing). In humans, the fertile sex is women and the fertile sex is men. In addition to gametes, an individual's gender is defined in biology on the basis of sex chromosomes, the genes connected to them that are necessary for determining sex, sex hormones, i.e. endocrinology, gonads, and the morphology of the external genitalia. Family reproduction involves combining and mixing genetic traits. When the gametes are similar in shape and function, we speak of isogamy and otherwise of anisogamy. The latter is more common in the organism. In addition to biology, gender can also mean social gender, which refers to the socially constructed aspects of masculinity and femininity

Athens' competition for Greek hegemony, i.e. supremacy, initially caused a smaller, so-called "first" Peloponnesian War, which was fought intermittently between 460 and 445 BC. The war ended in a peace treaty that did not please either side. War broke out between the cities again in 431 BC. According to the historian Thucydides, the Peloponnesian War was bigger and more significant than any previous war that had been fought in Greece. The war continued until the defeat of Athens in 404 BC. until. Athens had to give up its territories outside Attica, tear down the walls leading to its port city of Piraeus, and hand over its fleet. The popular rule extended under Pericles was met with a short-term decline in Athens after the war: the period of the thirty tyrants. WWF (World Wide Fund for Nature) is an international environmental organization founded in 1961. WWF's aim is to stop the deterioration of the environment and build a future where humanity lives in harmony with nature. At first, WWF focused on protecting endangered species such as tigers and polar bears, but since the 1980s, it has invested more in solving global environmental problems. WWF strives to influence the development of environmental legislation in different countries and the conclusion of international agreements, for example limiting emissions. The international president of WWF has been Yolanda Kakabadse from Ecuador since 2010, whose predecessor was Emeka Anyaoku. Liisa Rohweder has been the Secretary General of WWF Finland since 2009. Katharine Houghton Hepburn (May 12, 1907 Hartford, Connecticut – June 29, 2003 Old Saybrook, Connecticut) was an American film actress. She was nicknamed "First Lady of Cinema". In her more than 60-year career, Hepburn was nominated for an Oscar 12 times (among other actresses, only Meryl Streep has been more often) and received the award four times, more than any other actress. Hepburn became famous especially for her numerous films with Cary Grant and Spencer Tracy. In 1999, the American Film Institute chose her as the most outstanding actress of the century. Hepburn wrote an autobiography called "I". Katharine Hepburn was not related to another famous actress of the same time, Audrey Hepburn. Hepburn began her career in the theater in 1928.

The 200-member unicameral Parliament of Finland ("Eduskunta" (Finnish), "Riksdag" (Swedish)). It is the supreme legislative authority in Finland. The parliament may alter the Constitution of Finland, bring about the resignation of the Government, and override presidential vetoes. Its acts are not subject to judicial review. Legislation may be initiated by the Government, or one of members of Parliament, who are elected for a four-year term on the basis of proportional representation through open list multi-member districts.
